Award.AwardTitle: Harmonic Analysis and Partial Differential Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this proposal is to continue the PI's research on the development of various aspects of harmonic analysis and partial differential equations. The main focus of the PI's research will be the study of soliton resolution and blow-up properties of solutions to the energy critical wave equations and related models, the study of the global behavior of solutions to dispersive geometric flows, such as wave maps and Schrodinger maps, the study of periodic homogenization, the study of uniqueness and reconstruction in local inverse problems, the study of elliptic boundary value problems under minimal regularity assumptions and the study of quantitative unique continuation arising from localization problems in mathematical physics. This is a very ambitious and innovative program of research, which should develop new ideas and tools to treat important problems in the subjects mentioned above, which will have lasting consequences for the developments of these subjects and which builds on the PI's previous research accomplishments.

Many of the topics in the PI's research have their origins in problems coming from physics, engineering and medical imaging. In addition, the problems to be researched bring together in their study tools from different areas of mathematical analysis and geometry, further developing those areas. It is hoped that the synergy thus created will enrich all the fields involved. The research developed in the proposal will be the basis for graduate course, mini-courses and lectures by the PI. It will be disseminated widely through the publication of research papers, survey articles and monographs, through arXiv, a freely available electronic server of preprints, where the PI posts most of his preprints and through the PI's web page. In addition, this proposal will lead to topics of research for the PI's graduate students. The PI works actively to increase the participation in research of underrepresented groups. In this connection, the PI is very proud of his record of training female mathematicians as PhD students and postdocs. The PI hopes that the research in this proposal and its broad dissemination will lead to an even larger number of female graduate students and postdocs to be trained by the PI.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this project is the development of new ideas and methods to understand a variety of problems in partial differential equations and harmonic analysis. Some of the areas of research studied were nonlinear wave and dispersive equations, quantitative unique continuation and anisotropic inverse problems. These areas originate in fields such as nonlinear wave propagation, nodal geometry and medical imaging. In the area of nonlinear wave and dispersive equations, the PI and collaborators developed powerful new ideas and methods that have already had a broad impact in the field. With these new methods, the PI and collaborators have been able to solve long-standing problems on singularity formation and long-time asymptotics. In the area of quantitative unique continuation, the PI and collaborators have made breakthrough progress in obtaining advances to a (50 years old) conjecture of Landis. In the area of inverse problems, the PI and collaborators have been able to treat, in a unified way and in anisotropic settings, local uniqueness results.

The broad impact of this project is both scientific and educational. On the scientific side, the results and methods developed in this project will have impact in related fields such as optics, lasers, mathematical physics, material science, medical imaging and geophysical prospection. On the educational side, the PI has developed graduate courses based on this research. In addition, the PI has lectured extensively and has taught a number of summer courses based on this research. The results of the PI's research on this project have been widely disseminated through publication in leading specialized journals, the posting of preprints in electronic preprint servers and the PI's webpage. In addition, the PI has written a large number of survey papers giving expository accounts of his results on this project. The PI has been very actively involved in the training of young researchers on topics related to the project. During the duration of this project, the PI has supervised 8 graduate students, with 5 of them completing their PhD during this project, and the remaining 3 being at various stages of their dissertation research. The PI has also supervised and collaborated extensively with postdoctoral researchers, having supervised 10 of them during this project.
